The game is pretty solid for relaxation and becoming more aware of yourself and your body. The movements are very similar to Tai Chi and, for anyone that is new to this martial art, will help them learn how to be comfortable while performing many of the major movements.

With regard to features: the music and environment are both pleasant, with many options to choose from. If music or nature are not your thing, you can turn either or both off. The only major distraction was the guide. At times, the voice was a welcome corrective alert, making me aware that I had moved too fast. Other times, being told to become more aware of the Earth was irritating, and highly repetitive. That aside, it did prove useful on some occasions, especially if I started moving into a form that wasn't where the guide was headed.

On the topic of forms, there did not seem to be any clearly labeled forms, which was a major detractor for me. Part of value in Tai Chi is connecting to others, and without those labeled forms, we lose some of the history and connections to the culture it came from.

For a virtual reality instruction set, this is one of the better experiences I've had, especially with the semi-transparent demonstration dummy. It addresses one of the major problems with learning at home in that you normally cannot see what the instructor is doing on the side facing away from you. This was a beautiful touch of ingenuity that I must applaud.

Overall, this is a great addition to my library and I'd recommend it for anyone interested in body conditioning for Tai Chi or just plain relaxing. In the future, I would really appreciate the ability to turn off the voice-guidance. Putting in a visual cue, like gently fading the background to monochrome or having the controllers buzz only when moving completely out of the circles would be a good alternative and provide a more accessible experience for people with hearing impairments. An additional list with the names and movements for some of the better-known forms would also be a welcome improvement. Even without those things though, this is spot-on for an enjoyable 4 stars.
